column13: It depends on the days, sometimes if we have a big test coming up or a lot of homework to do, I would much rather spend the time studying than doing a communiy meeting. On the other hand, if it is a day where not much is going on, it can be a fun period and it can be insightful into how everyone is doing. But especailly during times when other stuff can be more important, community meetings are the last thing I’m worried about.
column22: Most teachers allow us to eat during class if we’re hungry, except for classes in the lab rooms, which is understandable, so I’m happy with that. The time we have lunch kind of works out cause it makes the school day seem to not drag, which I really like. The only problem is with the A/B days and club scheduling at lunch which is really a headache to remember and organize.
column29: I like the 8 period regular schedule we used previously
column30: The new schduel really does not work for the high school. Clubs are all a mess becasue of the new scheduling, with people not remember what days which clubs are on. There are usually scheduling conflicts with many things and sponsors are also confused which makes things even worse. On top of that, I feel like there are a lack of sponsors this year becasue of the new schduel as well. I would also like to have pathways back because it allowed us to use that time for productive things such as club meetings, dance practice, studying, and homework.
column31: 8 period regular schedule with a Short advisory with more Specials periods
column32: 8 period regular schedule with short morning advisory and a flexible 8th period like Pathways
column34: I would really like to bring pathways back the way it used to be last year.

column256: I feel like yes we all hate midterm season, but also I think it is a good idea to have them for college readiness. Office hours would also be nice the week leading up to midterms to have any questions we may have to be answered.

column13: When have we ever had extended advisory this year?
column22: Honestly, I believe that this was one of the worst changes this year. How can you expect high school—16 total classes—to eat in one period but split up 5th, 6th, 7th, and 8th grade—each 6 classes—into different periods? The schedule last year was absolutely fine, and from a student’s stand point, there is no reason to fix what isn’t broken. By attempting to do so, administration has only created an artificial issue. Additionally, just because food is allowed throughout the day does not mean that people have food to eat. Being hungry is not the only factor hindering learning performance either. Having 5 straight periods in a row without a break is arguably even more impactful. Finally, the issue about leaving early for sports has historically never been a significant issue for Masterman students because of the academic culture. Students understand that any missed work must be made up on their own time, and teachers were very understanding. If administration would actually consider student arguments (and no these surveys are not enough; acting on them would be enough), rather than assuming their ideas are best and neglecting student input, then perhaps, we could function more effectively as a school.

column219: High school electives should be option-based. Many high schoolers already had the experience of music and art in middle school. High school is a time for exploring possible interests. It’s fine in middle school to force students to explore different areas, but we should have more autonomy as high schoolers.

column13: I'm not a fan of the current schedule at all. Advisory is better in the mornings as it provides a buffer between getting to school and immediate learning, which helps students adjust and get into the ready-to-learn mentality before classes in the morning. Advisory after-school is too short to do much homework and it's often irritating to spend even more time in school after hours of learning, and with no good reason for it (like for example, a club or other useful activity.) Advisory at the end of the day just makes students feel like they are wasting time, while in the morning it provides a useful transition period. It is more beneficial to students to move it back to the end of the day.
column22: The time we eat lunch this year is too late. By the time it is lunch, my friends and I are famished and frustrated. 5 classes back-to-back before lunch is overly stressful, especially for us high schoolers who are already perpetually stressed and exhausted due to puberty and its effects (ex: changes in circadian rhythm, developing bodies.)

column30: I hate that all of those interesting classes and options were replaced with a longer advisory at the end of the day. I know that many people in my class prefer it at the end of the day, but even still it's way too long. We don't even do anything most of the time. My A/B schedule is literally the same thing except a different room for history, I liked it better when there was more variety. I also love art and music, and they were replaced with gym and gym only every day, and then we won't have gym for the rest of highschool which I think is stupid, it's not like one year of gym is gonna keep me in shape for the next 3 years. I never got to do the Pathways/Study Skills, but they seem really cool from what I heard, teaching uncommon skills and allowing people to leave early. I want to be an architect and I hear that there was something for that, so I especially don't like that it's gone.

column30: The current schedule makes the day slow. Teachers frequently comment on how tired the students seem because their lunch is so late. High school has lunch at around 1 pm and a lot of students with sports don't have time to eat and digest before going to play. Most of the time we rush to eat or eat on the bus right before we play. Advisory at the end of the day doesn't really benefit anyone. It doesn't give late students time to settle before the day starts and some kids would prefer to go home before the sky gets dark in the winter. The plus is that people can do their homework but pathways already did that.

column251: Right now, when we do physics labs, we have to put all of our carefully set up equipment away and put it back together the next day to complete a two-period experiment. This can (and usually does) affect our results since we may set it up slightly differently, or we may grab a different piece from the one we were using the day before or a different scale and they measure the results differently. For example, in 408, we were using one triple-beam balance to measure the masses of our objects on the first day and on the second day, we couldn't remember which scale we were using because they were all basically identical, and the scale we picked gave a different mass and we didn't have enough time to figure out which of the scales was the exact one we were using.

column22: The time we eat lunch is getting ridiculous. Our bodies were adjusted to eating at an earlier time and some of us don't want to eat in class as we have our chromebooks and materials. It's not fair to be at a school for seven years just to get disregarded and pushed aside so that middle school can eat separately. I don't mean to sound rude but it's simply not true that fifth grade has to eat separately. High school has over 400 students. One grade in middle school has less than 200. So why does high school have to be all together when each middle school grade has less students than us and "has" to eat separately. And for one excuse to be high school has sports and can leave during lunch is actually disgusting coming from mature adults. Yes, we are given lunch before we leave but this can actually make us really sick to not eat for a long period of time, then eat right before strenuous activity.

column13: It backfires, because many-not just me-students are uncomfortable sharing emotional and personal information with a group as big as a regular class. My advisor teacher seems uncomfortable for the same reason. The school is forcing us! So I try my best to opt out and stay silent. Compromise- Do the SEL stuff in regular classes, bc those teachers teach and know me. The advisors, unless they actually teach their whole advisory, don't have time to build normal relationships with their advisees given the way MHS works. I've even read books saying SEL should not be done in big classes. I've had enough of this... for years@
column22: I don't care about the roof. It's not my cup of tea. I think snack during a regular class is ridiculous. That's like doing your homework in your bed. It screws up the routine, so you can't sleep (which is what a bed is for). Same with class. Class is for class, not eating. When that happens, other corners are cut, and then class is not serious. Outlaw this idea. Or have a normal schedule.
column29: I like the 8 period regular schedule we used previously
column30: Oh my G-d, just reading these questions make me feel the 5th graders are smarter than the adults. Advisory doesn't even need to be every day. The best advice comes from people who get to know me and take time to find out who I am as a person. Good teachers do that. There are still a few here that qualify in that regard, but several who did left-are no longer here. I call my theory trickle-down-our administrators don't bet to know the school/the teachers, there is a pressure their, and then it trickles down from the teachers to us. Outside, generic solutions are not working, but they keep being forced on us since the pandemic.

column30: Every day gets super repetitive. having a different schedule each day of the week was much better for me. i do not like that advisory is so long now, because i would rather be able to do what i wanted (other clubs, sports, study hall.) i like having advisory at the end of the day, but i think i would rather have a short advisory and the beginning of the day, because it helps me wake up and get situated for the day. i dont mind the switch too much, but i do really wish it was more common for advisory to be study hall or easier to joint advisory clubs. i miss having art music and computers, because they were good breaks between the more rigorous classes, and also widened learning opportunities from pretty much only english and math, which it feels like makes up my whole day.

column43: Last year, I didn’t participate in many activities mostly because i am not talented enough for any of the athletic or music related clubs. if there were clubs that did not require tryouts or auditions that met during advisory, i would likely join those. i think the middle school, in general, is lacking any good sports teams. the only ones i know about are soccer and basketball, and i am good at neither. i joined soccer last year, but was sure i wouldn’t make the team this year so i didn’t try out. i would really enjoy if advisory could be very common for almost every student to be in a club or extracurricular, because that would really maximize the time we have and make advisory less useless.

column174: I really enjoy learning a language and being able to do that frequently. However, I think that having to give up your lunch and recess (only break during the day) to get specials is unnecessary and not beneficial. I enjoyed learning in specials. Also, access to a Language 1,2,3,4,5 is something that is very very important to me. This is not currently a part of the Mastermna curriculum. Chinese last year (i am in 8th grade) was useless, because we switched to French this year. In HS, there will be no opportunity to complete all French classes, and it feels ridiculous that it was removed. There is no straight path to Language 5, and instead we jump around from language to language each year and it feels like a waste of time. Please bring back French 1-5.
column266: I am one of the students that followed a curriculum where most thing students enjoyed are removed, so I can’t answer this. I wish that younger grades can have specials each year and the opportunity to fully master a language throughout middle and high school. The randomness of jumping from language to language is absolutely not what we need. The language course is a mess and majority of students will not reach where they could be in terms of fluency.

column174: Having specials is very important to me. First of all, as Masterman students, it is so important to have a well rounded education, including knowledge in music, art, language, and our bodies. When we have multiple periods of Math and Literacy, it can be draining for some students. That is my second point. Mental health is such a serious matter, especially within this age group. Some (including myself) see specials as a break and relaxation period to learn, but we can be more free and have more fun.

column13: I really enjoy the Late Advisory schedule, especially because my lunch is 5th period. It allows my first period to go by faster (mentally), and be a bit looser. SEL does not feel hurtful or annoying, it just does not seem too affective or useful.
column22: I think 5th period is my favorite time to have lunch, of my 4 years at masterman. I do not eat in the cafeteria (I’m autistic and i dislike it), so i don’t go to the roof either, but i do really like how my lunch period is scheduled, and i think that going to the roof is really good for kids even though i don’t do it.

column49: Musical ensembles (choir and the musical) for middle school in particular is quite literally hell. It is mostly composed of 5-6th graders, which means they are incredibly loud and off task. NOTHING gets done. Doctor Shapiro has to spend every 5 seconds telling everyone to be quiet and stop talking. There’s not enough order and i quit choir because these mentioned conditions were so stressful. It’s really difficult to feel prepared in my music when we never get enough formal teaching of it, and i am constantly distracted by talking or people singing wrong. When our rehearsals involve high schoolers, i feel uncomfortable and judged by them, and i feel they are often arrogant and judgmental towards middle schoolers as a whole. Like bro just because they can’t sing doesn’t mean you have to be a douchebag to me about it, you’re like 2 years older than me.

column266:
The GENUINELY glorious experience of having Mr. Olson as a teacher. I only had him for a few months because i was originally a Mr. Schuman kid, but dude he is an exquisite educator. By far my favorite masterman teacher.

Having Shapiro music lessons multi-weekly every year. They’re really enriching and i look back on them fondly.

Unique events such as big field trips, spirit week, contests, etc. I swear to god this new Masterman is killing fun.
column270: To the people who pushed for this survey, thank you so fucking much. I’m friends with a lot of highschoolers, and obviously I’m a student myself, and the lack of care for students our administration has is ridiculous and obscene. All of the questions asked are absolutely 100% necessary. They are all valid frustrations held by students and ignored by staff. I adore hearing anecdotes about the “old masterman”. Students deserve a voice. Your effort is appreciated by the student body. Keep doing what you’re doing. We deserve to be heard.

column270: I personally believe that the Forensics Honors course, a course that we were unaware of before the schedule came out for the current school year, is completely unfair and uneccessary considering the fact that the credits for this course are not needed to graduate. As a senior that takes 3 AP courses, I find it very difficult to keep up with all my classes plus another course that turned out to have a huge courseload (lots of tests, projects, and weekly assignments that are very long). I specifically did not take any science courses this year because that is not at all what I plan to study in college (business and economics) and I feel like I was cornered into taking this course. I was very excited to take no science courses and I am very happy with all my courses, but Forensics feels like an extra class that assigns so much work. Furthermore, as a senior I am also sending mid-year and final grades to colleges and I am afraid that Forensics is going to drag down my GPA (out of all my AP courses it is my lowest grade because it is hard to keep up with all my courses and all of the busywork and tests in Forensics).

column22: As a high schooler, I really appreciated having lunch in the middle of the day in prior years because it allowed me to take a break and refuel, get some last-minute homework/studying done, etc. between classes. Now, I have lunch after all 5 of my core classes, which means I have to sit through 5 consecutive class periods (over 4 hours) with no break in between. Not only is this exhausting, it is difficult to be fully prepared for 5 back-to-back classes, and to process 5 completely different sets of information with no break to let anything sink in or work/think further.

column30:
I truly have nothing positive to say about the new bell schedule. Frankly, it really sucks for us students and it's a major, major downgrade from what we had in previous years.

For the A/B schedule: It's impossible to keep track of "what day it is," and it's even harder to determine club scheduling when you have to remember not only what day it is, but what number of that day it is. It's also frustrating that our school schedules can no longer be coordinated with our outside schedules, such as knowing what classes I will be missing when I have a doctor's appointment, or knowing that I have room for more after-school commitments on certain days because I can get work done in senior seminar.

For the 7 period schedule: Pathways actually ended up being an incredibly valuable resource last year, and no longer having it has made things much more difficult. For starters, giving high school students a free period when middle school students had guidance allowed for more MS/HS connection, particularly through groups like Peer Counseling and QSA/Prisms, as well as making things like tutoring easier. These things have now shifted to the end-of-day advisory period, but not only is this 10 minutes shorter than Pathways was, which makes a significant difference, doing these activities now means that all students involved have to miss their own advisory. Advisory is an important time for connecting with peers and receiving important information/forms/etc. from advisors. Having advisory and pathways be two separate periods meant that we could do in-school activities at the end of the day and still get all the important benefits of going to advisory, but now that these activities are forced to be during advisory, most seniors rarely, if ever, go to advisory, and I would imagine the same is true for the rest of the high school. This makes it much more difficult to communicate information to all students, or to have important group discussions, and I think our community is generally weaker because of it.

For advisory being at the end of the day: I really appreciated having advisory in the morning because it allowed me to collect myself and get in the school mindset before going to class, as well as talk to my classmates and look over materials for any exams that day so they were fresh in my mind. Getting to school and having to go straight to class feels very jarring, and I feel like I am not ready to start class at 8:15, yet I'm forced to anyway, which decreases the quality of my learning. Also, I liked being able to sit in advisory at 7:50 or 8:00 when I got to school, but now I have to awkwardly wait in the hallway until 8:15, because at least in the library, we're not allowed to go into class until then. With advisory being at the beginning of the day, the period from around 7:45 to 8:15 was still sort of advisory, but now, that period is nothing, and it seems like no one knows what to do with it. As a result, large groups of students just stand in the hall outside every classroom starting at 8:00 or so, which makes it much harder to navigate the building, but also much harder to use that time productively: if I had access to a desk, I could get something done in those 10 or 15 minutes, but instead I just stand and go on my phone because there isn't really room to do work. Finally, I am usually on time to school, but arriving late for whatever reason happens sometimes, and I liked that advisory was sort of a buffer for that; now, if I'm even a few minutes late to school, I'm automatically missing class time, which is harmful, and quite frustrating.

column239: Madame Heimann's French class has been an integral part of my high school experience. Seeing Masterman starting to phase out French instruction for high school is really sad since it has been such a positive and beneficial experience for myself and my classmates. I sincerely hope administration continues the French program as a multi-year progression and not just a special class because it is a really valuable language to be proficient in by the end of high school, but also because Madame is such a great teacher and more students should have the opportunity to take her class.

column249: 5 instructional periods + 1 lab period (48 minutes each)
column251: We usually just do labs during class so that we don't have to come in at lunch, which I appreciate a lot, but it means that we have 4 periods of instructional time a week instead of 5, and we're potentially missing out on a lot of valuable class time. But if we use all 5 class periods, we have to miss clubs that we lead or other important lunchtime commitments, and some labs take more than 45-50 minutes, so we use some class time for them either way. However you look at it, not having a lab period is a lose-lose situation, and having it built in to the schedule is essential to getting the most out of a science class.
column256: Spread exams out more; the 1-per-day system this year is pretty good. column13: There is no "extended advisory." The SEL activities have good intentions, but they seem really forced. It personally doesn't engage my advisory and we end up wishing for them to be over. The advisories should be able to choose what dictates as a "SEL activity" each week.
column22: Roof access during the winter isn't as important, but when the weather gets better it definitely will be. I usually eat lunch during 4th period because of 6th period lunch, but I shouldn't have to resort to eating two periods earlier. Sometimes I'll snack during advisory because if I eat 4th and not during 6th, I'll be hungry again.

column30: Our current advisory period should be cut into two separate advisory periods: morning and end of the day. A morning advisory would allow me to settle in, study, and relax before heading to 1st period. I also like having an advisory at the end of the day to unwind and organize myself before leaving. If not two separate advisory periods, then a study hall like we had last year would be great. It doesn't have to take up an entire period and it could replace our advisory. The freshmen had the lunchroom last year: it was great because people could study, socialize, and it was a time to unwind. My sole plea is for something to be done about the end-of-the-day advisory.

column85: The Summer Bridge program definitely helped me adjust to high school when I was a freshman, especially being a "lottery kid." I liked Masterman a lot during the first semester, but the pressure of the Masterman community got to me at times. It still kinda does to this day. Masterman was and is built on being a successful and academic-driven school. I felt a bit surprised at how seriously my peers took their studies and the school.

column22: There is no reason to have lunch at one o'clock for high school students. We only have one more period left in the day and it is ridiculous our lunch is so late. Our teachers let us eat snacks in class but we need to be able to have a lunch without having to disturb the class or our time that we get to do work. The idea of combining middle school lunches would work well for everyone as all of the high school eats lunch together so there shouldn't be an issue for two middle school grades to have lunch together. It is ridiculous that this idea has been shut down so many times without explanation.

column13: I personally do like advisory at the end of the day because it gives me time to relax and recap on my day. I get to go over my homework most of the time when we aren't doing anything and communicate with others and ask for help on my homework when I don't understand. This helps me because I don't have to struggle and I am able to ask a teacher instead of doing it myself and not understanding. Also I get to work with others on classwork that I may have not finished and even help others.
column22: I feel as if the students should have more of a choice for roof access. I understand that the weather is not always acceptable but if students aren't allowed to go out on a day that they are able to play their sport, but the next day they are able to, they should be able to have a make up day. I feel this is unfair if you don't allow make-up days because some kids look forward to recess on the roof because it may be the only time they have access to play or even interact with others in a way they enjoy. Personally, I don't really have access to playing outside and do a sport I enjoy due to my schedule so everyday I look forward to going on the roof to play volleyball with my friends since it is something I enjoy. So whenever it is unexpectedly not allowed that day (sometimes even if the weather is acceptable) I get disappointed. I also feel that going on the roof for both A days and B days should be at the same time. Some days we go out earlier and some days we go out later.
